Tech Stack

Front End Languages:

  • HTML5 & CSS3 - I keep up to date with best practices, and am always looking for new creative ways of maximizing the Front End experience while understanding limitations of backwards compatibility. I strive to maintain "Empathetic Markup" so anyone can jump right in and understand what is going on.

  • Javascript & Jquery - A brief overview of the lifecycle of JS:
    I Know... How to write my own custom JS solutions. Why a plugin might make more sense. And when to hack a plugin or when to cut bait and go back to custom.

  • SASS & Jeet & Jekyll- SASS is so powerful and an effective way to promote reusability and maintainability. Currently I have been using the Jeet grid system for creating responsive layouts minus all the bloat of Bootstrap or Foundation. Jeet runs on SASS, so for front-end only projects, I have been using the Jekyll static site generator (endorsed by GitHub pages) to power the SASS dependency of Jeet, and spin up high fidelity prototypes very quickly.

  • Backbone & Node - Typically I have used Backbone to help organize what javascript effects what content. And Node as a service to interface with APIs and third party data structures.

Back End Languages:

  • Ruby on Rails - This is my strongest backend programming language. I have built robust Content Management Systems using polymorphic models, Google Maps API integration, custom Social Media scapers/engines.

  • PHP & Wordpress- I have worked with PHP to build a robust backend in Wordpress to allow client service teams to manage content and effortlessly create responsive newsletters. While working in PHP was a learning experience and I was able to achieve what I originally intended, Ruby seems to be born out of the ashes of PHP and solves a lot problems with much less effort.

  • Servers & Databases- I know how to setup a Linux server from scratch, using some combination of Apache or Puma. And how to setup up staging and production environments, and deploying code updates. My database of choice is MYSQL given its native compatibility with Rails Projects.

Chicago Based Web Development

Email Marketing is another "Necessary Evil" of Web Development. Given the various platform in which people check their emails you have to code like it's 1999 to ensure your message is received as designed (even if people are still using Outlook 2007). I am up-to-date with best practices, CAN-SPAM compliance, even cutting edge responsive layout solutions.
